The '''CHIPS and Science Act''' is a U.S. federal statute enacted by the [[117th United States Congress]] and signed into law by President [[Joe Biden]] on August 9, 2022. The act provides roughly 280 billion dollars in new funding to boost domestic research and manufacturing of [[semiconductors]] in the United States.<ref name="Politico 20220809">{{Cite web |last=Johnson |first=Lamar |date=August 9, 2022 |title=Biden ends slog on semiconductor bill with signature |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/08/09/biden-ends-slog-on-semiconductor-bill-with-signature-00050530 |access-date=August 9, 2022 |website=[[POLITICO]] |language=en}}</ref>  The law does not have an official short title as a whole but is divided into three divisions with their own short titles: Division A is the '''CHIPS Act of 2022''' (where CHIPS stands for "Creating Helpful Incentives to Produce Semiconductors"); Division B is the '''Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act'''; and Division C is the '''Supreme Court Security Funding Act of 2022'''.<ref>{{Cite web |last= |first= |date=2022-08-09 |title=Text - H.R.4346 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): Supreme Court Security Funding Act of 2022 |url=http://www.congress.gov/ |access-date=2022-09-11 |website=U.S. Congress}}</ref>

It channeled more than $52 billion into researching semiconductors and other scientific research, with the primary aim of countering China. The bill passed the [[U.S. Senate]] by a vote of 64–33 on July 27, 2022.<ref name=":0">{{cite news |last1=Sprunt |first1=Barbara |title=Legislation to subsidize U.S.-made semiconductor chips heads to Biden's desk |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/07/26/1113470753/chip-production-semiconductor-senate |access-date=August 6, 2022 |work=NPR |date=July 27, 2022}}</ref> On July 28, the $280 billion bill passed the [[U.S. House]] by a vote of 243–187–1.<ref name="verge-clears-congress" /><ref>{{cite news |last1=Breuninger |first1=Kevin |title=Biden to sign bill boosting China competition and U.S. chip production |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/02/biden-signs-china-competition-bill-to-boost-us-chip-production.html |access-date=August 5, 2022 |work=CNBC |date=August 2, 2022}}</ref>

== Background and provisions ==
The bill was considered amidst a [[2020–present global chip shortage|global semiconductor shortage]] and intended to provide subsidies and tax credits to chip makers with operations in the United States. The [[U.S. Department of Commerce]] was granted the power to allocate funds based on companies' willingness to sustain research, build facilities, and train new workers.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Swanson |first1=Ana |title=Congress Is Giving Billions to the Chip Industry. Strings Are Attached. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/03/business/economy/chip-industry-congress.html |access-date=August 5, 2022 |work=The New York Times |date=August 3, 2022 |url-access=subscription}}</ref>

For semiconductor and telecommunications purposes, the CHIPS Act designates roughly $106 billion. The CHIPS Act includes $39 billion in tax benefits and other incentives to encourage American companies to build new chip manufacturing plants in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web |title=What's in the recently passed CHIPS Act? |url=https://usafacts.org/articles/whats-in-the-recently-passed-chips-act/ |access-date=2022-08-15 |website=USAFacts |language=en}}</ref> Additionally, $11 billion would go toward advanced semiconductor research and development, with $8.5 billion going to the [[National Institute for Standards and Technology]], $500 million for [[Manufacturing USA]], and $2 billion for a new public research hub called the National Semiconductor Technology Center. $24 billion would go to a new 25 percent advanced semiconductor manufacturing tax credit to encourage firms to stay in the United States, and $200 million would go to the [[National Science Foundation]] to resolve short-term labor supply issues.<ref name="McKinsey 2022"/><ref name="CSIS 2022"/>

According to [[McKinsey]], "The CHIPS Act allocates $2 billion to the [[US Department of Defense]] to fund microelectronics research, fabrication, and workforce training. An additional $500 million goes to the [[US Department of State]] to coordinate with foreign-government partners on semiconductor supply chain security. And $1.5 billion funds the USA Telecommunications Act of 2020, which aims to enhance competitiveness of software and hardware supply chains of open RAN ([[radio access network]]) [[5G]] networks."<ref name="McKinsey 2022">{{cite web |last1=Badlam|first1=Justin|last2=Clark|first2=Stephen|last3=Gajendragakar|first3=Suhrid|last4=Kumar|first4=Adi|last5=O’Rourke|first5=Sara|last6=Swartz|first6=Dale|title=The CHIPS and Science Act: Here's what's in it | website=McKinsey & Company | date=4 October 2022 | url=https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/public-and-social-sector/our-insights/the-chips-and-science-act-heres-whats-in-it | access-date=5 October 2022}}</ref><ref name="CSIS 2022">{{cite web | last1=Kersten | first1=Alexander | last2=Athanasia | first2=Gabrielle | last3=Arcuri | first3=Gregory | title=A Look at the CHIPS-Related Portions of CHIPS+ | website=Center for Strategic and International Studies | date=9 August 2022 | url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/look-chips-related-portions-chips | access-date=5 October 2022}}</ref> Companies are subjected to a ten-year ban prohibiting them from producing chips more advanced than 28-nanometers in China and Russia if they are awarded subsidies under the act.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Debby Wu |author2=Daniel Flatley |author3=Jenny Leonard |title=US to Stop TSMC, Intel From Adding Advanced Chip Fabs in China |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-08-02/us-to-stop-tsmc-intel-from-adding-advanced-chip-fabs-in-china |access-date=13 August 2022 |work=Bloomberg |date=2 August 2022}}</ref>

The act authorizes $174 billion for uses other than semiconductor technology.<ref name="McKinsey 2022"/><ref name="CSIS 2 2022"/> It authorizes, but does not appropriate, extended [[NASA]] funding for the [[International Space Station]] to 2030, partially funds the [[Artemis program]] returning humans to the Moon, and directs NASA to establish a Moon to Mars Program Office for a [[human mission to Mars]] beyond the Artemis program. The bill also obligates NASA to perform research into further domesticating its supply chains and diversifying and developing its workforce, reducing the [[environmental effects of aviation]], integrating [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] detection with [[air traffic control]], investigating [[nuclear propulsion]] for spacecraft, continuing the [[search for extraterrestrial intelligence]] and [[xenology]] efforts, and boosting [[astronomical survey]]s for [[Near-Earth object]]s including the [[NEO Surveyor]] project.<ref name="Politico 20220809"/><ref name="Errick 2022">{{cite web | last=Errick | first=Kirsten | title=NASA Authorization Act Aims to Strengthen U.S. Space Exploration | website=Nextgov.com | date=4 August 2022 | url=https://www.nextgov.com/emerging-tech/2022/08/nasa-authorization-act-aims-strengthen-us-space-exploration/375394/ | access-date=24 August 2022}}</ref>

The bill could potentially invest $67 billion in accelerating advanced zero-emissions technologies to mass markets and improving [[climate science]] research, according to the climate action think tank [[Rocky Mountain Institute]]. The bill would invest $81 billion in the NSF, including new money for [[STEM]] education and defense against foreign [[intellectual property infringement]], and $20 billion in the new [https://beta.nsf.gov/tip/latest Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships], which would be tasked with deploying the above technologies, and authorizes but does not appropriate $12 billion for [[ARPA-E]].<ref name="Atlantic 20220810">{{cite web | last=Meyer | first=Robinson | title=Congress Just Passed a Big Climate Bill. No, Not That One. | website=The Atlantic | date=2022-08-10 | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2022/08/chips-act-climate-bill-biden/671095/ | access-date=2022-10-05}}</ref> It contains annual budget increases for the [[United States Department of Energy]] for other purposes including [[supercomputer]], [[nuclear fusion]] and [[particle accelerator]] research, and directs the [[United States Department of Commerce]] to establish $10 billion worth of research hubs in post-industrial, mostly rural economies.<ref name="McKinsey 2022"/><ref name="CSIS 2 2022">{{cite web | last1=Arcuri | first1=Gregory | last2=Shivakumar | first2=Sujai | title=A Look at the Science-Related Portions of CHIPS+ | website=Center for Strategic and International Studies | date=11 August 2022 | url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/look-science-related-portions-chips | access-date=5 October 2022}}</ref>

Every senator in the [[Senate Democratic Caucus]] except for [[Bernie Sanders]] voted in favor of passing the CHIPS Act, and they were joined by seventeen Republican senators, which included Senate Republican leader [[Mitch McConnell]], Utah senator [[Mitt Romney]], and South Carolina senator [[Lindsey Graham]].<ref name=":0" />

== Impact ==
In October 2022, [[Micron Technology]] announced it will invest $20 billion in a new chip factory in [[Clay, New York]] to take advantages of the subsidies in the act.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Chipmaker Micron to build $20 billion N.Y. factory amid semiconductor boom |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/04/micron-chip-factory-new-york/ |access-date=2022-10-05 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |date=2022-10-04 |title=Micron Pledges Up to $100 Billion for Semiconductor Factory in New York |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/04/technology/micron-chip-clay-syracuse.html |access-date=2022-10-06 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

== Reception ==

=== Support ===
Many legislators and elected officials from across both the federal government and various state governments endorsed the passage. A bipartisan group of governors consisting of Pennsylvania's [[Tom Wolf]], Alabama's [[Kay Ivey]], California's [[Gavin Newsom]], Kentucky's [[Andy Beshear]], Michigan's [[Gretchen Whitmer]], Wisconsin's [[Tony Evers]], Illinois' [[J. B. Pritzker]], Kansas' [[Laura Kelly]], and North Carolina's [[Roy Cooper]] pushed for the passage of the bill back in November 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-11-10 |title=Governor Wolf, Bipartisan Governors Urge Congress to Pass CHIPS Act to Create American Jobs, Boost Semiconductor Production |url=https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/governor-wolf-bipartisan-governors-urge-congress-to-pass-chips-act-to-create-american-jobs-boost-semiconductor-production/ |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=Governor Tom Wolf |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Governors urge passage of CHIPS Act funding to spur semiconductor 're-shoring' {{!}} InsideTrade.com |url=https://insidetrade.com/daily-news/governors-urge-passage-chips-act-funding-spur-semiconductor-%E2%80%98re-shoring%E2%80%99 |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=insidetrade.com}}</ref>

Separately, Ohio governor [[Mike DeWine]], whose state became the home of [[Intel]]'s newest [[semiconductor fabrication plant]] in the [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]] suburb of [[New Albany, Ohio|New Albany]], as well as Texas governor [[Greg Abbott]] and Texas senator [[John Cornyn]], whose state was the home of a major investment from [[Samsung]], each pushed for the bill to be passed and applauded at its advancement through Congress.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-07-28 |title=Congress passes CHIPS Act, paving way for microchip plant in Ohio |url=https://www.news5cleveland.com/news/state/congresss-passage-of-chips-act-paves-way-for-intels-microchip-plant-in-ohio |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=WEWS |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=BeMiller |first=Haley |title=Intel CEO: Company moving 'full speed ahead' on Ohio plans after CHIPS Act passes Congress |url=https://www.dispatch.com/story/news/2022/07/28/chips-act-four-ohio-republicans-boost-bill-pushed-intel/10176845002/ |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=The Columbus Dispatch |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Moneyhon |first=Carl H. |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/anb/9780198606697.article.0400249 |title=Coke, Richard (1829-1897), governor of Texas and U.S. senator |date=2000 |publisher=Oxford University Press |series=American National Biography Online|doi=10.1093/anb/9780198606697.article.0400249 }}</ref> It has received widespread support from chip firms, though they were concerned about the provision banning them from further investments in China.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nellis |first1=Stephen |date=20 July 2022 |title=Chip designers warm to U.S. bill despite big benefits to Intel |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/us-chip-industry-split-over-chips-act-benefits-intel-sources-2022-07-18/ |access-date=5 August 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author1=Cheng Ting-Fang |author2=Lauly Li |author3=Yifan Yu |date=2 August 2022 |title=CHIPS Act leaves chipmakers facing choice between U.S. and China |work=NIKKEI Asia |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Tech/Semiconductors/CHIPS-Act-leaves-chipmakers-facing-choice-between-U.S.-and-China |access-date=5 August 2022}}</ref>

=== Opposition ===
The bill was criticized by Republican House leader [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]] and senator [[Bernie Sanders]] as a "blank check", which the latter equated to a bribe to semiconductor companies.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="verge-clears-congress">{{cite news |last1=Kelly |first1=Makena |title=CHIPS Act clears Congress, ensuring $52 billion boost to US foundries |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/7/28/23282494/semiconductors-chips-and-science-act-joe-biden-congress-nvidia |access-date=5 August 2022 |work=The Verge |date=28 July 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=NEWS: Sanders Opposes All Blank Checks to Chip Companies » Senator Bernie Sanders |url=https://www.sanders.senate.gov/press-releases/news-sanders-opposes-all-blank-checks-to-chip-companies/ |access-date=2022-09-09 |website=Senator Bernie Sanders |language=en-US}}</ref> China lobbied against the bill and criticized it as being "reminiscent of a 'Cold War mentality{{'"}}.<ref>{{Cite web |last=O'Meara |first=Sean |date=2022-07-29 |title=China Says US Chip Act Will Harm Supply Chain, Global Trade |url=https://www.asiafinancial.com/china-says-us-chip-act-will-harm-supply-chain-global-trade |access-date=2022-08-09 |website=Asia Financial |language=en-US}}</ref>
